text.p: Queensland's bowlers tore through
a near test strength New South Wales batting line-up on Sunday
to set up an almost certain win in their Sheffield Shield match.
In a worrying sign ahead of the first test between Australia
and West Indies which starts on Friday, Queensland dismissed New
South Wales in their second innings for 141 on the third day.
Australia captain Mark Taylor and test batsmen Mark Waugh
and Michael Slater all failed, Taylor making 15, Slater three
and
Waugh a duck.
Steve Waugh followed his first innings century by
top-scoring with 35. Adam Dale, Geoff Foley and Scott Muller
each took two wickets for Queensland.
The second innings capitulation by New South Wales left
Queensland needing just 108 to win and, but for rain
shortening the day's play by an hour, they could have reached
their target with a day to spare.
At stumps Queensland were 44 for one, with Trevor Barsby 30
not out and Martin Love two after opener Troy Dixon was bowled
by leg-spinner Stuart MacGill for 12.
In Melbourne, South Australia reached 214 for five in their
second innings but were still 47 runs behind Victoria's first
innings total going into Monday's final day.
South Australia were forced to follow on after being bowled
out for a paltry 84 on Saturday. Geoff Parker led an apparently
hopeless fight with 52 not out in the second innings.
In Perth, Justin Langer and Tom Moody scored centuries to
rescue Western Australia from a parlous position in their
rain-affected match against Tasmania.
Langer and Moody put on 213 for the fourth wicket after
Western Australia had been in trouble at 64 for three.
Moody, in the hope of forcing a result, declared his side's
innings closed at 326 for four in reply to Tasmania's first
innings 473 for four declared.
That tactic appeared to backfire as Tasmania reached 133
without loss at stumps on the third day, a lead of 280.
